text: Consume them in wrath, consume them, that they may not be: and let them know that God ruleth in Jacob unto the ends of the earth. Selah.

text_nasb: Destroy [them] in wrath, destroy [them] that they may be no more; That [men] may know that God rules in Jacob To the ends of the earth. Selah.
context: Psalm 59 is a plea for deliverance from enemies. David, the traditionally attributed author, likely wrote it during a period when King Saul was actively pursuing him, seeking to kill him. 1 Samuel 19 details such an event where Saul sent men to watch David's house and kill him in the morning. The Psalm reflects a sense of immediate danger and imminent threat. The 'sons of violence' mentioned throughout the Psalm refer to these antagonists, likely Saul's agents or supporters. The imagery is vivid, painting a picture of predatory behavior: the enemies are likened to dogs circling and waiting to attack. The Psalm's repetitive structure highlights the relentless nature of the threat and David's desperate need for God's intervention. 'Jacob' is used synonymously with Israel, representing God's covenant people, and invoking the history of God's chosen nation. The Selah provides a pause for reflection, marking a shift in tone or emphasis within the Psalm. The geographical scope, 'unto the ends of the earth,' suggests that God's rule and sovereignty are not limited to Israel but encompass the entire world, underscoring the universal implications of God's justice. The Psalm's intense language reflects the harsh realities of ancient warfare and political intrigue, where betrayal and violence were common tools used against perceived enemies.
meaning: Psalm 59:13 expresses a powerful, even unsettling, desire for God's judgment upon David's enemies. The repetition, 'Consume them in wrath, consume them,' emphasizes the intensity and urgency of David's plea. This isn't merely a request for temporary setbacks or minor inconveniences for his enemies; it's a plea for their complete and utter destruction. The purpose behind this annihilation is not solely for David's personal safety or vindication. The verse clearly states, 'that they may not be,' suggesting a desire to prevent further wickedness and protect others from future harm. This aligns with the Old Testament understanding of God's justice as not only restorative but also retributive, aimed at maintaining order and righteousness in the world. The phrase 'and let them know that God ruleth in Jacob unto the ends of the earth' highlights a theological purpose. David's desire is for his enemies to recognize God's sovereignty and dominion. Their consumption would serve as a tangible demonstration of God's power and authority, not only over Israel (Jacob) but also over the entire world. This is a testament to God's universal kingship. The verse underscores the Old Testament theme of God's covenant faithfulness to His people, protecting them from their enemies, and demonstrating His power to all nations. The 'Selah' calls for contemplative reflection on the awesome power and justice of God revealed in this verse. This is not necessarily an endorsement of personal vengeance, but rather a recognition of God's ultimate justice and His role as the righteous judge of all.
application: Applying Psalm 59:13 in a modern context requires careful consideration, as we are called to love our enemies and pray for those who persecute us (Matthew 5:44). This verse should not be interpreted as a license for personal vengeance or hatred. Instead, it offers a perspective on dealing with injustice and evil in the world. We can apply this verse by praying for God to deal justly with those who perpetrate evil, whether on a personal, societal, or global scale. This means praying for the end of corrupt systems, the conversion of wrongdoers, and the protection of the vulnerable. It also calls us to actively work against injustice and oppression, seeking to create a more equitable and righteous world. We should not passively accept evil but actively resist it while maintaining a spirit of love and compassion. The call to ‘let them know that God ruleth’ reminds us to be witnesses to God’s power and sovereignty in our lives and in the world. This means living lives that reflect God’s character, speaking truth to power, and challenging injustice wherever we find it. It means trusting that God will ultimately prevail over evil, even when it seems overwhelming. When facing personal attacks or persecution, we can draw strength from David's example of trusting in God's protection and seeking His justice. Instead of seeking revenge, we can pray for God to vindicate us and to use the situation to demonstrate His power and glory. Finally, this verse challenges us to examine our own hearts and ensure that we are not harboring bitterness or resentment. We must forgive those who have wronged us and seek reconciliation whenever possible, recognizing that God's grace extends even to our enemies. We must actively love our enemies.
prayer: Sovereign God, Your power extends to the ends of the earth, and Your justice is unshakeable. I come before You acknowledging the presence of evil in the world and in my own life. I pray for Your righteous judgment on injustice, oppression, and wickedness. Help me to resist evil without succumbing to hatred or bitterness. Fill me with Your compassion and grace, that I may love even my enemies. Reveal Your power and sovereignty to those who deny You, that they may know that You are the Lord. Grant me the strength to be a witness to Your truth and righteousness in all that I do. Use me to bring healing and reconciliation to a broken world. Protect me from the snares of the wicked and keep me steadfast in Your love. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: While the Psalm expresses a desire for destruction, we must interpret it through the lens of the New Testament's call to love our enemies. Pray for their transformation, for justice, and for God's will to be done, avoiding personal vengeance.
